Randy Hembrador
UX designer

Footprint Collective

Making sustainability more sustainable

Background

Many want to help the environment, but few explicitly track and manage their personal carbon footprint regularly. Reasons for the discrepancy range from unfamiliarity with the concept to overwhelm from its complexity and potential pervasiveness.

Objective
Design a solution that helps users get familiar with their carbon footprint, and manage it in a way that’s sustainable in everyday life.

Image source: The Sierra Club

Carbon Footprint

Our project operated on the understanding that

  • A “carbon footprint” is the measure of one’s carbon emissions based on their activities and lifestyle choices
  • Footprints can be measured for anything from a person to a planet
  • Lifestyle choices can be changed to reduce one's carbon footprint and overall negative impact on the environment
Image source: co2living.com

Timeline

3-week group project

Project Scope

User research and analysis, 2 design sprints for onboarding UX, and initial prototype

Role

UX/Researcher, Research Analyst, UX Designer

Tools

Whimsical, Miro, Figma, Google Office

Research

Outset

Within our design team, all members considered themselves to be environmentally conscious, but no one regularly tracked and managed their own footprint.

Our research plan sought to find if that was generally true, what might influence the choice to track, and how engagement might be increased.

Interviews and Surveys

To ask these questions, we conducted 5 interviews and a 25-person survey. Similar to our internal team, 92% of the respondents were either open or wanted to track their carbon footprint, but a staggering 0 actually did.

Based on our findings, major causes appeared to be:

  • Unfamiliarity with what’s possible
  • A preference for lifestyle changes that don’t need to be tracked
  • The sense that tracking can be overwhelming and/or intrusive
Text
Quote from research interview

And while no one tracked their carbon footprint, respondents had many other ways of expressing passionate conscientiousness from converting their homes to solar and attending environmental conferences to avoiding drive-thrus to reduce emissions.

Our research indicated that the following were (or can be) powerful general motivators for adopting environmentally-friendly behavior:

  • Information of anykind
  • Knowledge of what others are doing
  • Friendly competition
Image source: The Sierra Club
Definition & Ideation

Meet Greg

Based on our research, we developed an empathy map for a user named Greg with the thoughts, words, deeds, and feelings shown in the image.

Pain points for Greg include the cost of footprint tracking - both monetary (such as the price of an electric car) as well as the effort to stay informed, consider the potential carbon impact of almost every action, and stay motivated to keep tracking and make changes.

Our team aims to help Greg with the following...

Image source: The Sierra Club

Problem statement

Footprint Collective was created in order to provide environmentally conscious individuals a way to connect with others in their community, as well as to provide them with easy to access information in order to gain actionable awareness of their personal impact allowing them to make educated and sustainable changes.

Competitive Analysis

Currently, Greg does have access to some tools to help him with Carbon Footprint tracking. We considered the value he might gain from them as well as the challenges he might run into based on the motivators and deterrents identified in our research.

Based on the analysis, we saw that the biggest potential areas for innovation were constant updates through passive data collection, socialized information exchange, and engagement through gamification.

Image source: The Sierra Club

I Like, I Wish, What If...

Our team used the "I like, I wish, What if..." brainstorming method to determine the direction of our design solutions.

Given the limited timeline and scope of the project, we decided to mainly focus on the "I Wish" portion of our results which generally fell into 3 categories

  • Having accurate info to work with
  • Reducing manual data entry as much as possible
  • Having a steady stream of new information to work with
Image source: The Sierra Club

Feature Prioritization

Identifying the highest priority work was also critical given the limited timeline and scope of the project.

To accomplish this, we created a 2x2 complexity-to-impact matrix. Although several group members were highly passionate and excited about potential gamification aspects, we all ultimately aligned on data accuracy and simplification of data entry as the highest priority items.

Image source: The Sierra Club

User Journey

Our team used the "I like, I wish, What if..." brainstorming method to determine the direction of our design solutions.

Given the limited timeline and scope of the project, we decided to mainly focus on the "I Wish" portion of our results which generally fell into 3 categories

Image source: The Sierra Club
Prototyping

Plotting the Experience

To achieve our goal of simplifying data entry, we included several steps in the onboarding taskflow that would establish a foundation for passive data collection.

These steps would let Greg connect the app to his local utility account and have the app track his commuting habits for him so that he can get accurate data with minimal need for manual data entry.

  • Having accurate info to work with
  • Reducing manual data entry as much as possible
  • Having a steady stream of new information to work with
Image source: The Sierra Club

Plotting the Experience

To achieve our goal of simplifying data entry, we included several steps in the onboarding taskflow that would establish a foundation for passive data collection.

These steps would let Greg connect the app to his local utility account and have the app track his commuting habits for him so that he can get accurate data with minimal need for manual data entry.

Image source: The Sierra Club

Low-Fi Prototype

We stitched together our low-fi wireframes in Figma to identify whether there were any unforeseen confusing elements in our design, and developed a test-plan based on the experience we hoped to provide for Greg.

Our test plan for the prototype focused on

  • X
  • Y
  • Z
Image via the Sierra Club
Testing & Iterating

Next Steps

If we were to take the project further, we'd next focus on the following...

  • Perform further design iterations on the quiz functionality to improve clarity and data quality
  • Improve clarity for the flows used to build out the user’s contact list
  • Begin to design functionality for how users connect and interact with each other through the app

...from there, our next design focus would be how we collect the missing data points, like food servings and airplane travel

And from there, we’d have the data foundation to really start delivering on the promise of the app, and start designing the features around personalized recommendations, building groups, and engaging in community challenges with a sustainability impact

Randy Hembrador
